drug.name: Magnesium trisilicate
drug.description: Magnesium trisilicate is an inorganic compound that is used as an antacid in the treatment of peptic ulcers.
drug.indication: For the treatment of peptic ulcers. Relieving indigestion and heartburn.
drug.pharmacodynamics: Magnesium trisilicate works by increasing the pH of gastric juice via a neutralisation reaction. It also precipitates colloidal silica, which can coat gastrointestinal mucosa conferring further protection.
drug.mechanism-of-action: The gelatinous silicon dioxide, formed by the reaction of magnesium trisilicate with gastric contents is said to protect ulcerated mucosal surfaces and favor healing.
drug.toxicity: Adequate doses of magnesium trisilicate may cause diarrhea due to the action of soluble magnesium salts in the enteric tract. Approx 5% of the magnesium is absorbed.
drug.absorption: The hydrated silicon dioxide formed in the stomach and passes into the intestinal track where, silica can be partly absorbed.
drug.volume-of-distribution: The hydrated silicon dioxide formed in the stomach and passes into the intestinal track.
drug.clearance: Maximum magnesium clearance is directly proportional to creatinine clearance.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of inorganic compounds known as alkaline earth metal silicates. These are inorganic compounds in which the largest oxoanion is silicate, and in which the heaviest atom not in an oxoanion is an alkaline earth metal.
